Award.AwardTitle: Towards Dispersion Management and Coherent Plasmon Optics in Nanostructured Metallodielectric Composites
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: This project aims for greater understanding, development, and optical characterization of new metallodielectric nano-composite materials. Dispersion of the dielectric permittivity, as arising from composition, structure and symmetry is a primary issue of concern, because it enables control, creation and detection of optical information, since new dispersive phenomena are now known to arise in micro and nanostructured materials. The approach addresses such dispersive response in selection of nanostructured metallodielectric composite materials, referred to as metamaterials, and study of linear optical response of metallodielectric composites in the context of three fundamentally distinct dispersion management protocols: (i) Starting with nanostructured composites, effective material permittivities will be measured, delineating their dependence on symmetry, scale and order. (ii) At the meso-scale, plasmon mode-coupling in quasi two-dimensional metallodielectric photonic crystals will be studied in the context of a coherently-induced transparency. (iii) At the material level, coupling of the metallodielectric structures to a resonant gain medium will allow active control over metamaterial dispersion. The integrated results of this study are expected to result in a more comprehensive and fundamental understanding of dispersion management in both active and passive metamaterials. Since the project addresses fundamental questions of light-matter interactions in nanoscale plasmonic systems, results and knowledge gained will be relevant to understanding signal manipulation in sub-diffraction volumes in the presence of strong dispersion. Such understanding is expected to have impact in fields such as light harvesting, nanoscale signal routing and storage, high-resolution imaging systems and active plasmonic devices.
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of electronic/photonic materials science with high technological relevance. Current development of photonic devices capable of manipulating optical information may substantially impact advancement of present and future optical technologies. The proposed research is interdisciplinary in nature, offering collaborative opportunities for all participating students. A goal is to make known the many fascinating aspects of materials science by exposing university students of all levels to research and multi-disciplinary scientific work. At the undergraduate level the aim is to expand avenues for learning by offering a variety of course and research opportunities. At the graduate level the project addresses involvement and development of existing educational and internship programs, both in materials science and optics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This project addresses fundamental problems in optics of complex materials, which are potentially relevant to developing technologies. The research aims to develop understanding of structure-related optical and electronic properties of metals textured on a hierarchy of length scales, ranging from several nanometers to microns, and their potential applications in technologies such as solar energy harvesting and advanced sensing systems.

 

Specifically, this project studies plasmonics as a means to address many of the relevant questions in the field. Broadly defined, plasmonics involve the study of optical phenomena mediated by light confined to the interfaces between metals and other, non-conducting materials. These interfaces are often structured on the nanoscale. In recent years there has been rapidly growing interest in plasmonics research, driven by applications in vastly different areas, encompassing chemical sensing, dense information technologies, solar energy conversion, and optical cloaking (i.e. the ability to render an object invisible using an appropriately designed material shroud) to name just a few.

 

Research efforts on this project have led to the development of knowledge in two distinct sub-fields of plasmonics. In the first, we addressed the physics of metals exhibiting structural features across several length scales. We have developed reproducible fabrication methods of such materials, as well as detailed studies pertaining to their physical properties. The second focus has been on fundamental aspects of plasmonics, such as nonlinear interactions and plasmonic sensing.

 

When studying multi-scale structured silver films, we first developed a Monte Carlo-based computer program which simulates multi-scale film deposition in 3D. The main strength of our approach is in its source of input parameters: all experimental data are obtained using digital image analysis of our metal films. Through analysis of such sequential 2D projected images we were able to formulate a statistically accurate deposition model in 3D. We then implemented this method in our analysis of light emission from these films. We found that the emitted light is strongly correlated with the interface density in the films, as measured using our simulations results. Simply stated, by measuring interface density using digital image analysis we were able to demarcate the onset of structural changes in our films, and also estimate the number of nanoscale features contributing to the light emission.

 

It is known that the tight interfacial confinement of plasmons enables strong nonlinear optical interactions. To address this effect, we conducted an analytical study of plasmonic propagation at a nonlinear silver-vacuum interface. We obtained a steady state solution showing a third harmonic generation process, where the input plasmon induces the generation of light with frequency three times greater than its own. This new wave is unique, in that it propagates only semi-bound at the interface, causing the high frequency radiation to be emitted into the metal.

 

In a separate project, we addressed the known sensitivity of plasmonic systems to their environment, and developed a new plasmonic temperature sensor. The apparatus employs a low-power laser, requiring only a single wavelength and interrogation angle for rapid and accurate characterization. The device is particularly suited for precise diagnostics of transparent fluids, such as many of the fluids used in bio-microfluidic systems as well as gases in flow microreactors. The sensor may also be readily integrated into existing lab-on-chip platforms by incorporating an optical interrogation window.
